Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Feature]: Adding Azure domain to Trusted Domain" (#9498) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Related Problem

At this moment is not possible to embed in the markdown the Release badge from Azure DevOps Pipeline.
The domain that hosts the badge is: vsrm.dev.azure.com

Meanwhile dev.azure.com is in the Trusted Domains, **vsrm**.dev.azure.com is not.

Thank you, best

### The Elevator Pitch

Just adding Release badges in the README.md would be nice ;)

### Additional Context and Details

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[NuGet.org Bug]: Can't install package, but .net version is right." (#9497) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Impact

I'm unable to use NuGet.org

### Describe the bug

I want to install PowerShell package by Microsoft in VSCode, but I'm getting this weird error: 
```
error: NU1202: Package PowerShell 7.3.4 is not compatible with net7.0 (.NETCoreApp,Version=v7.0). Package PowerShell 7.3.4 supports: net7.0 (.NETCoreApp,Version=v7.0) / any
error: NU1212: Invalid project-package combination for PowerShell 7.3.4. DotnetToolReference project style can only contain references of the DotnetTool type 
error: Package 'PowerShell' is incompatible with 'all' frameworks in project 'd:/Projects/Eva/Source/Eva.csproj'.
```

### Repro Steps

Steps to reproduce:
1. Open Nuget Gallery
2. Search for PowerShell package.
3. Try to install package

### Expected Behavior

Package should install fine lol

### Screenshots

_No response_

### Additional Context and logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[A11y][ScreenReader]More Information link on search results page is ambiguous" (#9423) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Url: https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/1745384

Environment Details:
App name: NuGet Service
#URL: [https://www.nuget.org](https://nam06.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https:%2f%2fwww.nuget.org%2f&data=05%7c01%7cv-nitipi%40microsoft.com%7c9a84307e7aa744a4b24208dafa5ca2fe%7c72f988bf86f141af91ab2d7cd011db47%7c1%7c0%7c638097573052590837%7cUnknown%7cTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7c3000%7c%7c%7c&sdata=C8Eab3i6ixAmqsOjG4AxNT36z9WZQiXPbjDDkMcS5ME%3D&reserved=0)

OS and Browser Details:
Edition Windows 11 Enterprise
OS build 22621.1105.
Chrome version:  109.0.5414.120 (Official Build) (64-bit)
Screen reader: JAWS, NVDA

Repro Steps:
Hit the URL: https://www.nuget.org/
Navigate to "Sign in" control and hit enter.
Navigate to "Sign in with Microsoft" control and hit enter.
Search for a key term (say ‚Äújson‚Äù) from search box.
"Packages returned for json" screen gets opened.
Check whether "More Information" link is descriptive or not.

Notes:
It should be sufficient for us to augment the More Information link to read "More Information about {PackageId}"

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[A11y]Screen reader starts over from beginning when applying filters." (#9422) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Url: https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/1749979

Environment Details:
App name: NuGet Service
#URL: [https://www.nuget.org](https://nam06.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https:%2f%2fwww.nuget.org%2f&data=05%7c01%7cv-nitipi%40microsoft.com%7c9a84307e7aa744a4b24208dafa5ca2fe%7c72f988bf86f141af91ab2d7cd011db47%7c1%7c0%7c638097573052590837%7cUnknown%7cTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7c3000%7c%7c%7c&sdata=C8Eab3i6ixAmqsOjG4AxNT36z9WZQiXPbjDDkMcS5ME%3D&reserved=0)

OS and Browser Details:
Edition Windows 11 Enterprise
OS build 22621.1105.
Chrome version:  109.0.5414.120 (Official Build) (64-bit)
Screen reader: JAWS, NVDA

Repro Steps:
Hit the URL: https://www.nuget.org/
Navigate to "Sign in" control and hit enter.
Navigate to "Sign in with Microsoft" control and hit enter.
Search for a key term (say ‚Äújson‚Äù) from search box.
"Packages returned for json" screen gets opened.
Tab till filter present at left side of screen and apply any filter.
Observe that screen reader is announcing all the details from the beginning when we apply filter.

Actual Result:
Screen reader is announcing all the details from the beginning when we apply filter.

Expected Result:
Screen reader should not announce all the details from the beginning when we apply filter, it should only announce the status message that "812 packages returned for json"

Notes:
Unfortunately, I believe this is relatively nontrivial to fix on our side. From my understanding of this issue and the feature, this is caused by the fact that hitting applying appear to redo the search with filters enabled, causing a page refresh. When the page refreshes, context on keyboard nav etc is lost. In theory, it should be possible to pass context to the next page, but I am unsure that this the right fix long term.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[A11y][ScreenReader]Package Manager tab on Package details reads as both selected and expanded" (#9418) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Url: https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/1744434

Environment Details:
App name: NuGet Service
#URL: [https://www.nuget.org](https://nam06.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https:%2f%2fwww.nuget.org%2f&data=05%7c01%7cv-nitipi%40microsoft.com%7c9a84307e7aa744a4b24208dafa5ca2fe%7c72f988bf86f141af91ab2d7cd011db47%7c1%7c0%7c638097573052590837%7cUnknown%7cTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7c3000%7c%7c%7c&sdata=C8Eab3i6ixAmqsOjG4AxNT36z9WZQiXPbjDDkMcS5ME%3D&reserved=0)

OS and Browser Details:
Edition Windows 11 Enterprise
OS build 22621.1105.
Chrome version:  109.0.5414.120 (Official Build) (64-bit)
Screen Reader: JAWS, NVDA

Repro Steps:
Hit the URL: https://www.nuget.org/
Navigate to "Sign in" control and hit enter.
Navigate to "Sign in with Microsoft" control and hit enter.
Search for a key term (say ‚Äújson‚Äù) from search box.
Click on "Newtonsoft.json" control and hit enter.
Navigate to "PackageReference" control and hit enter.
Observe whether screen reader should announce only one state as 'selected' or not.

Actual Result:
Screen reader is announcing two states as 'selected and expanded' for "package reference" tab item.

Expected Result:
Screen reader should announce only one states as 'selected' for "package reference" tab item.

Notes:
These controls appears to have aria-expanded defined on them for some reason. I am unsure why this is the case, but it seems like removing it will address the issue here. However, I don't know what other issues it might introduce.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[A11y][ScreenReader]Compatible Framework tab does not convery compatible vs computed additional frameworks" (#9421) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Url: https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/1746058

Environment Details:
App name: NuGet Service
#URL: https://dev.nugettest.org/

OS and Browser Details:
Edition Windows 11 Enterprise
OS build 22621.1105.
Chrome version:  109.0.5414.120 (Official Build) (64-bit)
Screen Reader: JAWS.

Repro Steps:
Hit the URL: https://dev.nugettest.org/
"NuGet" screen will open.
Tab to search button and press enter.
"Packages" screen will open then tab to any package like "Newtonsoft.Json " and select it by pressing enter key.
"Newtonsoft.Json " package screen will open.
Tab to "Frameworks" tab and press enter.
Observe whether screen reader is not announcing as a Compatible target framework(s) for dark blue color version.

Actual Result:
Screen reader is not announcing category of framework for version which are differentiated with color. For ex. Compatible target framework(s) for dark blue color version.

Expected Result:
Screen reader should announce category of framework for version which are differentiated with color.

Notes:
The screen reader on this is already fairly verbose. I am unsure how we would do this without making even more verbose. It may be ok to increase the verbosity, but it doesn't feel like a good solution to me.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Package Source Mapping status for selected package in Details Pane" (#12586) at NuGet/Home
Closed issue "[Bug]: Msbuild Timeout Exception on NuGet command" (#12571) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
---
**Issue moved from dotnet/msbuild#8703**
- Please respond to @DONAR144-release.

---

_From @DONAR144-release on Tuesday, April 25, 2023 11:08:35 AM_

### Issue Description

The NuGet command stage in my DevOps pipelines fails intermittently on the same commits. This behavior is non-deterministic and the pipeline will usually run to completion when triggered again.

### Steps to Reproduce

This has happened across a few of my pipelines all using similar version of the following YAML file. The application is an Azure Function app targeting .NET 6


trigger:
  branches:
    include:
    - main
    - develop

pool:
  vmImage: 'windows-latest'

variables:
  solutionGeneralApi: '**/SOLUTIONNAMEREDACTED.sln'
  buildPlatform: 'Any CPU'
  buildConfiguration: 'Release'

steps:
- task: NuGetToolInstaller@1

- task: NuGetCommand@2
  inputs:
    restoreSolution: '$(solutionGeneralApi)'

- task: DotNetCoreCLI@2
  inputs:
    command: publish
    arguments: '--configuration Release --output publish_output'
    projects: '$(solutionGeneralApi)'
    publishWebProjects: false
    modifyOutputPath: false
    zipAfterPublish: false

- task: ArchiveFiles@2
  displayName: "Archive files"
  inputs:
    rootFolderOrFile: "$(System.DefaultWorkingDirectory)/publish_output"
    includeRootFolder: false
    archiveFile: "$(System.DefaultWorkingDirectory)/GeneralApi.zip"

- task: VSTest@2
  inputs:
    platform: '$(buildPlatform)'
    configuration: '$(buildConfiguration)'

- task: PublishBuildArtifacts@1
  inputs:
    PathtoPublish: '$(System.DefaultWorkingDirectory)/GeneralApi.zip'
    artifactName: 'drop'


### Expected Behavior

Running restore with 2 concurrent jobs.
Reading project file D:\a\1\s\FOLDERNAMEREDACTED\SOLUTIONNAMEREDACTED.csproj.
Restoring packages for D:\a\1\s\FOLDERNAMEREDACTED\SOLUTIONNAMEREDACTED.csproj...
Restoring packages for .NETCoreApp,Version=v6.0...

### Actual Behavior

2023-04-25T09:10:39.1353098Z NuGet Version: 6.5.0.154
2023-04-25T09:10:39.1353546Z MsBuild timeout out while trying to get project to project references.

### Analysis

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "dotnet list package --format json --include-transitive includes project references as transitive packages." (#12585) at NuGet/Home
Opened issue "Warn when ProjectReference conditions may lead to missing assets (`DllNotFoundException`: `The specified module could not be found.`)" (#12584) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product(s) Affected

Visual Studio Package Management UI

### Current Behavior

It's a known problem that `packages.config` does not support transitivity for runtime assembly references. There is nothing in VS to point out that such a `ProjectReference` is in effect.

### Desired Behavior

Consider a UX that can highlight this scenario to customers before they get into trouble. 
Some ideas: 
1. a warning stating that a project reference uses PR, while your consuming project uses PC, and this can lead to unexpected behavior. 
2. Point to a new docs page with an example of a package where this would occur, and how to workaround it via `dotnet publish`, or similar. Also, can link to the PackageReference migrator instructions in case that's an option for the customer.

### Additional Context

An example package and exception is below. These .SNI assemblies are runtime dependencies, so t
The SNI has a targets file that is manually copying them to the output directory.

> System.DllNotFoundException: 'Unable to load DLL 'Microsoft.Data.SqlClient.SNI.x64.dll': The specified module could not be 
found. (Exception from HRESULT: 0x8007007E)'

Example ticket: https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/t/DLL-not-found-for-NuGet-package/10338932

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Support viewing README files in Visual Studio" (#12583) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product(s) Involved

Visual Studio Package Management UI

### The Elevator Pitch

Last December, it was announced that you can edit and render markdown files now in Visual Studio. 

https://devblogs.microsoft.com/visualstudio/write-markdown-without-leaving-visual-studio/

It is a regular ask from the developer community to be able to read READMEs of packages while they are inside the PM UI whether browsing or getting started with a NuGet package. 

Developers should see a README in a tab similar to the [NuGet.org re-designed tabs](https://devblogs.microsoft.com/nuget/introducing-the-new-nuget-org-package-details-page/):

![image](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/assets/1288848/e9f08ccb-2f34-4b25-9d8f-a27e439cc304)

Inside of Visual Studio:

![image](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/assets/1288848/bb080e1d-5a8f-4be7-b116-660fc193a2ff)


### Additional Context and Details

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Transitive packages don‚Äôt show in the ‚ÄúInstalled‚Äù tab until setting the ‚ÄúNUGET_TRANSITIVE_DEPENDENCIES_IN_PMUI‚Äù‚ÄØenvironment variable " (#12582) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

Visual Studio Package Management UI

### Product Version

NuGet Client Dev\6.7.0.38

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Repro Steps & Context

#### Repro Steps:‚ÄØ‚ÄØ 
1. Create a .NET Core Console App project via VS. ‚ÄØ 
2. Right-click the project in Solution Explorer and select ‚ÄòManage NuGet Packages‚Ä¶‚Äô menu item to open PM UI. ‚ÄØ 
3. Click ‚ÄúBrowse‚Äù tab, search a package (e.g. ‚ÄúMicrosoft.EntityFrameworkCore‚Äù) that has dependencies, select a package version ‚Äú6.0.4‚Äù in the "Version" drop-down list in the right panel and click the ‚ÄúInstall‚Äù button on the right. ‚ÄØ 
4. Click ‚ÄúOK‚Äù button in the ‚ÄúPreview Changes‚Äù dialog and click ‚ÄúI Accept‚Äù button in the ‚ÄúLicense Acceptance‚Äù dialog. ‚ÄØ 
5. Go to ‚ÄúInstalled‚Äù tab.‚ÄØ 

#### Expected:‚ÄØ‚ÄØ 
Transitive packages should show in the ‚ÄúInstalled‚Äù tab. ‚ÄúTransitive packages‚Äù label is expanded by default and all the transitive packages showed in the ‚ÄúTransitive packages‚Äù list (under the ‚ÄúTop-level packages‚Äù list).‚ÄØ 

#### Actual:‚ÄØ‚ÄØ 
Transitive packages don‚Äôt show in the ‚ÄúInstalled‚Äù tab as below screenshot.‚ÄØ 
![image](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/assets/84695155/716abd8c-870a-4ddb-aa28-77cb5f76b186)
#### Notes:‚ÄØ 

1. The repro rate is 80%.‚ÄØ‚ÄØ 
2. The issue will not repro after setting the ‚ÄúNUGET_TRANSITIVE_DEPENDENCIES_IN_PMUI‚Äù‚ÄØenvironment variable to‚ÄØ1 and reopen the same solution. 
3. it also repro on VS Main\33710.149 + NuGet Client Dev\6.7.0.36. 

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Moving to the new .NET Foundation CLA service" (#68) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
Hello everyone
The .NET Foundation is transitioning to a new CLA service and I'm posting here to let you know it's happening. Some background info:

The new CLA service is based off of https://github.com/microsoft/ContributorLicenseAgreement, except it uses the dotnet-policy-service app

- Current contributors do not need to sign the CLA again
- The CLA agreement itself is not changing
- As part of the install/configuration process, the following work items will be completed

1. Create a .github repo if it doesn't exist already
2. Install the dotnet-policy-service app
3. Create PRs for the platformcontext.xml and cla.yml files
4. Disable the existing CLA webhook
5. Push the PRs to enable the new CLA service

That's all there is to it. I'll update this issue once the work is complete

Thanks
Chris
.NET Foundation Operations team

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Moving to the new .NET Foundation CLA service" (#68) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
Hello everyone
The .NET Foundation is transitioning to a new CLA service and I'm posting here to let you know it's happening. Some background info:

The new CLA service is based off of https://github.com/microsoft/ContributorLicenseAgreement, except it uses the dotnet-policy-service app

- Current contributors do not need to sign the CLA again
- The CLA agreement itself is not changing
- As part of the install/configuration process, the following work items will be completed

1. Create a .github repo if it doesn't exist already
2. Install the dotnet-policy-service app
3. Create PRs for the platformcontext.xml and cla.yml files
4. Disable the existing CLA webhook
5. Push the PRs to enable the new CLA service

That's all there is to it. I'll update this issue once the work is complete

Thanks
Chris
.NET Foundation Operations team

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "NuGet.org migration towards a new multi-CDN infrastructure" (#60) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
In the coming weeks, nuget.org will be migrating towards a new multi-CDN infrastructure that will improve the experience of our users. This change allows our team flexibility to switch to a back-up provider in the case that one CDN is down, which will broaden coverage for our users.

Some changes are coming for older TLS cipher suites, which may result in connectivity issues. From our data we believe this will affect only a small percentage of requests. We will be monitoring all feedback channels during the migration to assess impact and adjust our roll-out timeline as needed.

Below, we provide resources to determine whether you will be affected by this change. This utilizes the [.NET CLI](https://dotnet.microsoft.com/) to install a package from our pre-production (INT) environment which tests connectivity:


```
mkdir cdn-test
cd cdn-test
dotnet new classlib
dotnet add package BaseTestPackage.NetStandard --source https://apiint.nugettest.org/v3/index.json
```

If you are experiencing connectivity issues while connecting to nuget.org or restoring packages from https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json, such as:

"The SSL connection could not be established"

Please ensure that TLS 1.2 and any of the following cipher suites have been enabled on your machine:

TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384
TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256
TLS_DHE_RSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384
TLS_DHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256

If you have any questions, do reach out to us at‚ÄØsupport@nuget.org or by commenting on the discussion issue:‚ÄØNuGet/Home#11058
